fr.spacefox.confusablehomoglyphs

Class Confusables

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.spacefox.confusablehomoglyphs.Confusables

  • public class Confusables
extends java.lang.Object
    A collection of tools to check if a given string contains characters that can be confused with other one.
    Version:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    SpaceFox

      • fromInternal

        public static Confusables fromInternal()
        Create an instance of Confusables and load associated JSON data. As the loading is relatively long, this object should be kept alive.
        Returns:
        an initialized instance of Confusables
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the JSON data can't be loaded

      • isMixedScript

        public boolean isMixedScript(java.lang.String string,
                             java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> allowedAliases)
        Checks if string contains mixed-scripts content, excluding script blocks aliases in allowed_aliases.
        E.g. B. C is not considered mixed-scripts by default: it contains characters from Latin and Common, but Common is excluded by default. 
             >>> confusables.isMixedScript("Abç")
     False
     >>> confusables.isMixedScript("ρτ.τ")
     False
     >>> confusables.isMixedScript("ρτ.τ", Collections.emptyList())
     True
     >>> confusables.isMixedScript("Alloτ")
     True
        Parameters:
        string - A unicode string
        allowedAliases - Script blocks aliases not to consider.
        Returns:
        Whether string is considered mixed-scripts or not.

      • isMixedScript

        public boolean isMixedScript(java.lang.String string,
                             java.lang.String... allowedAliases)
        Same as isMixedScript(String, Collection) but with allowed aliases as string array.
        Parameters:

        allowedAliases - Script blocks aliases not to consider.

        See Also:

      • isMixedScript

        public boolean isMixedScript(java.lang.String string)

        Parameters:
        string - A unicode string
        Returns:
        Whether string is considered mixed-scripts or not.
        See Also:

      • isConfusable

        public java.util.List<Output> isConfusable(java.lang.String string,
                                           boolean greedy,
                                           java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> preferredAliases)
        Checks if string contains characters which might be confusable with characters from preferredAliases.
        If greedy == false, it will only return the first confusable character found without looking at the rest of the string, greedy == true returns all of them.
        preferredAliases == [] can take a list of unicode block aliases to be considered as your "base" unicode blocks:
        • considering paρa,
          • with preferredAliases == ["latin"], the 3rd character ρ would be returned because this greek letter can be confused with latin p.
          • with preferredAliases == ["greek"], the 1st character p would be returned because this latin letter can be confused with greek ρ.
          • with preferredAliases == [] and greedy == true, you'll discover the 29 characters that can be confused with p, the 23 characters that look like a, and the one that looks like ρ (which is, of course, *p* aka *LATIN SMALL LETTER P*).
             >>> confusables.isConfusable("paρa", Collections.singleton("latin"))[0].character
     "ρ"
     >>> confusables.isConfusable("paρa", Collections.singleton("greek"))[0].character
     "p"
     >>> confusables.isConfusable("Abç", Collections.singleton("latin"))
     []
     >>> confusables.isConfusable("AlloΓ", Collections.singleton("latin"))
     []
     >>> confusables.isConfusable("ρττ", Collections.singleton("greek"))
     []
     >>> confusables.isConfusable("ρτ.τ", Arrays.asList("greek", "common"))
     []
     >>> confusables.isConfusable("ρττp")
     [{"homoglyphs": [{"c": "p", "n": "LATIN SMALL LETTER P"}], "alias": "GREEK", "character": "ρ"}]
        Parameters:
        string - A unicode string
        greedy - Don't stop on finding one confusable character - find all of them.
        preferredAliases - Script blocks aliases which we don't want string's characters to be confused with.
        Returns:
        all confusable characters and with what they are confusable otherwise.

      • isConfusable

        public java.util.List<Output> isConfusable(java.lang.String string,
                                           boolean greedy,
                                           java.lang.String... preferredAliases)
        Same as isConfusable(String, boolean, Collection) but with allowed aliases as string array.
        Parameters:

        greedy - Don't stop on finding one confusable character - find all of them.

        See Also:

      • isDangerous

        public boolean isDangerous(java.lang.String string,
                           java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> preferredAliases)
        Checks if string can be dangerous, i.e. is it not only mixed-scripts but also contains characters from other scripts than the ones in preferredAliases that might be confusable with characters from scripts in preferredAliases.
        For preferredAliases examples, see isConfusable. 
             >>> bool(confusables.isDangerous("Allo"))
     False
     >>> bool(confusables.isDangerous("AlloΓ", Collections.singleton("latin")))
     False
     >>> bool(confusables.isDangerous("Alloρ"))
     True
     >>> bool(confusables.isDangerous("AlaskaJazz"))
     False
     >>> bool(confusables.isDangerous("ΑlaskaJazz"))
     True
        Parameters:
        string - A unicode string
        preferredAliases - Script blocks aliases which we don't want string's characters to be confused with.
        Returns:
        Is it dangerous.

      • isDangerous

        public boolean isDangerous(java.lang.String string,
                           java.lang.String... preferredAliases)
        Same as isDangerous(String, Collection) but with allowed aliases as string array.
        Parameters:

        preferredAliases - Script blocks aliases which we don't want string's characters to be confused with.

        See Also:
